seg.seg: ... with ... hands, having approached the Buddha-god the teacher,
(having placed both knees on the ground, whispering ...) paying his respect to (the Buddha-god) the teacher, says: || In the Maitär [tune] || (The efforts) of Asaṃkhyeyas
... to the difficult-to-obtain jewel of Buddha rank. Having become a father
... (The Buddha-god the teacher) says: What is the noble pleasure among the mortals? || The noble Metrak says:
... oh venerable one! || The Buddha-god the teacher says: Which guise ... you ... for your own (good) as well as that of others?
... The noble Metrak says: The guise of monkhood, oh venerable one! || The Buddha-god the teacher says: Good,
... in sixty Kalpas, the Mahāśrāvakas accumulate merits; in the end, having taken on the guise of monkhood, (they attain the rank of an) Arhat

(For) in sixty kalpas the mahāśrāvakas accumulate merits; in the end, having taken on the guise of monkhood, (they attain the rank of an) arhat; (in hundred kalpas), the (khaḍgaviṣāṇa)kalpas accumulate merits; in the end, having taken on monkhood, they attain the rank of a pratyekabud- dha. (in hundred kalpas and in three asaṃkhyeya-periods the Buddhas, the teachers), accumulate (merits); in the end, with the guise of a monk, seated on the diamond throne, they attain the perfect Buddha rank. Those who are … (Bodhisattvas now), in the end, when they have gone away from the house towards the Buddha-god and taken on the guise of a monk, (they attain the ordination) of a royal heir. (cf 131; 363, 365)
... the ... accumulate merits; in the end, having taken on monkhood, they attain the rank of Pratyekabuddha.
... accumulate (merits); in the end, seated on the diamond throne, they attain the perfect Buddha rank.
... if they become ..., in the end, having gone away from the house to the Buddha-god and taken on the guise of a monk (they attain) ... of princedom.
... God Brahmā says to God Indra: Certainly indeed, now the noble Metrak ... the Buddha-god the teacher
... having made obvious the great joy in the Buddha-god the teacher - see, oh renowned one,
... surrounded by a halo having ...; slim like the three-day-old moon
... with the wish for monkhood, toward the Buddha-god (with) insatiable (eyes?)
... by giving up ..., he cannot bring forth this merit.
... (Therefore, everybody) has the limitless desire (for the venerable Maitreya to leave the house). || Thereupon

p.note: This fragment contains part of the second act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; the Uy. parallel would be MaitrHami II, 14-15, which, however, is missing. A parallel text can be found in a(‹ b)2-b(‹ a)7, which corresponds to a5 through a6 here and roughly to MaitrHami II, 13b2-15(?). See also 195-6.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 132.

Cf. : a(› b)3, end of the fragment. Hereafter, the Tocharian text should find its equivalent in the 15th leaf of the Uyghur version. Li collected some fragments of this leaf, which had been believed to be lost.
For the restored first part of this line, cf. : a(› b)4. maitraṃ is a stanza of 4 x 12 (5/7) syllables.
/// [:] m[ā]ski: this reading is possible if the little piece at the beginning of line b6 of the photo is taken into account. (Michaël Peyrot)
For mäñcaṃ a variant mant caṃ exists in : a (> b) 6.

The collocation ktsets puttiśparäm has its parallel in : a5 sne lyutār ktsets puttiśparäṃ, which corresponds to Skt. anuttara-samyak-sambodhi; therefore, ktsets equals Skt. samyak and is to be translated as ‘perfect, complete’.
The form ñwasaṃ is new, and probably matches TB ñweṃne, referring to the new moon (195); therefore, tre-yo should be an instrumental: ‘by three (days)’.
The restorations are based on 365. We are deviating from their translation by taking lyutār memaṣ to be an attribute of the noun ñās, following the suggestion by Sergey Malyshev.
130 read instead of . Based on the photograph, the former is clearly incorrect. We thank Sergey Malyshev for pointing this issue out to us. (Cf. also 307.)
